articles.headline: The Old Are Working, but Not the Young
articles.snippet: People over 60 are more likely to have jobs than at any time in at least three decades. But younger workers are still having trouble finding jobs.
articles.abstract: People over 60 are more likely to have jobs than at any time in at least three decades. But younger workers are still having trouble finding jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: This summer has seen a larger share of a certain group of people working than at any time in the last three decades, according to government figures.

articles.headline: Waiting to Woo Vodafone, and Paying the Price
articles.snippet: With the benefit of hindsight, Verizon should simply have paid whatever Vodafone wanted, since it was so much less than what it is paying now.
articles.abstract: With the benefit of hindsight, Verizon should simply have paid whatever Vodafone wanted, since it was so much less than what it is paying now.
articles.lead_paragraph: Verizon’s agreement to acquire Vodafone’s stake in Verizon Wireless is a megadeal by any measure: at $130 billion it ranks as the third-largest ever, and the largest since the collapse of the dot-com bubble in 2000.

articles.headline: If ‘Million Second Quiz’ Succeeds, NBC Gets the Grand Prize
articles.snippet: NBC’s new quiz show, starting on Monday, is getting attention for its unspoken ambition: proving that broadcast TV still matters.
articles.abstract: NBC’s new quiz show, starting on Monday, is getting attention for its unspoken ambition: proving that broadcast TV still matters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pop quiz: what does broadcast television need right now?

articles.headline: Bank of America to Pay $39 Million in Gender Bias Case
articles.snippet: The settlement comes on the heels of a big payout last week for a racial discrimination lawsuit.
articles.abstract: The settlement comes on the heels of a big payout last week for a racial discrimination lawsuit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bank of America agreed on Friday to pay $39 million to women who worked in its Merrill Lynch brokerage operation, another costly settlement of a discrimination case filed by its employees.

articles.headline: Bold Play by CBS Fortifies Broadcasters
articles.snippet: CBS and its chief, Les Moonves, have given the broadcast world a shot in the arm by pushing distributors to pay broadcasters just as they do cable networks.
articles.abstract: CBS and its chief, Les Moonves, have given the broadcast world a shot in the arm by pushing distributors to pay broadcasters just as they do cable networks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Leslie Moonves, the longtime chief executive of CBS, has heard the jokes about CBS being old and out of step because of the age of its audience and because it does not have enormous assets in the cable network world.

articles.headline: Tighter Rules Will Make It Harder to Get a Reverse Mortgage
articles.snippet: Reverse mortgages, through which people over 62 can tap home equity, are getting streamlined rules to protect both borrowers and lenders.
articles.abstract: Reverse mortgages, through which people over 62 can tap home equity, are getting streamlined rules to protect both borrowers and lenders.
articles.lead_paragraph: The spigot on reverse mortgages has been slowly tightened over the last several years. Borrowers can no longer tap as much of their home equity as they could before the housing crisis.

articles.headline: A University Band, Chastened by Hazing, Makes Its Return
articles.snippet: Nearly two years after a drum major was beaten to death by fellow band members in a hazing ritual, the Marching 100 of Florida A&M University is back on its home turf.
articles.abstract: Nearly two years after a drum major was beaten to death by fellow band members in a hazing ritual, the Marching 100 of Florida A&M University is back on its home turf.
articles.lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — Knees sprang up, way up, as the students stepped into their slow march during practice this week. Sweat cascaded down their bodies, but they held the pose, five seconds, again and again. Then, they burst across the field, horns and drums at full blast, in frenzied precision.

articles.headline: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Has Plan to Add Millions of Nonunion Members
articles.snippet: Richard Trumka, the labor federation’s president, says a broad coalition could help restore the labor movement’s clout.
articles.abstract: Richard Trumka, the labor federation’s president, says a broad coalition could help restore the labor movement’s clout.
articles.lead_paragraph: Richard L. Trumka, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., has a bold plan to reverse organized labor’s long slide: let millions of nonunion workers — and perhaps environmental, immigrant and other advocacy groups — join the labor federation.

articles.headline: A Weapon Seen as Too Horrible, Even in War
articles.snippet: Chemical weapons have caused only a small fraction of the deaths in Syria’s civil war, but the response they have provoked echoes that from wars around the world during the 20th century.
articles.abstract: Chemical weapons have caused only a small fraction of the deaths in Syria’s civil war, but the response they have provoked echoes that from wars around the world during the 20th century.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Wilfred Owen, the British soldier-poet, wrote in his best-known work, “Dulce et Decorum Est,” an effort to depict the horrors of chemical warfare, “If you could hear, at every jolt, the blood / Come gargling from the froth-corrupted lungs.”

articles.headline: At Virgin America, a Fine Line Between Pizazz and Profit
articles.snippet: An airline whose sleek style rates highly with its passengers is still struggling to make money for its investors, and has lost $675 million since 2007.
articles.abstract: An airline whose sleek style rates highly with its passengers is still struggling to make money for its investors, and has lost $675 million since 2007.
articles.lead_paragraph: ON Monday, June 17, at 6:30 a.m., Robin Wolaner boarded a flight from San Francisco to Seattle. An executive for a nonprofit organization, Ms. Wolaner was no mere traveler. She was bounty, the kind of frequent flier who makes or breaks airline profits, and she’d been snared by Virgin America.

articles.headline: Find the Loan Behind the Loans
articles.snippet: When regulators accuse financial firms of predatory lending, shouldn’t they track down where these firms are getting their capital?
articles.abstract: When regulators accuse financial firms of predatory lending, shouldn’t they track down where these firms are getting their capital?
articles.lead_paragraph: ONLINE lenders who charge borrowers stratospheric interest rates are coming under pressure from state regulators — and it’s about time. But to get at the root of the problem, the regulators may need to dig much deeper.

articles.headline: From Myspace’s Ashes, Silicon Start-Ups Rise
articles.snippet: Almost every member of Myspace’s founding team has begun a new venture, and many are among the leaders of Los Angeles’s blossoming start-up industry, Silicon Beach.
articles.abstract: Almost every member of Myspace’s founding team has begun a new venture, and many are among the leaders of Los Angeles’s blossoming start-up industry, Silicon Beach.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT is hardly uncommon for founders and employees of successful companies to cash in their chips and go on to start other successful companies. Perhaps the best-known example is PayPal, the Web payment service whose leaders went on to found and invest in a bunch of other companies — YouTube, LinkedIn, Yelp, Tesla — and to earn the nickname the PayPal mafia.

articles.headline: Obama’s Battle for Syria Votes, Taut and Uphill
articles.snippet: People on Capitol Hill said the initial campaign for strikes against Syria proved unpersuasive, but administration officials insist the debate will continue when Congress returns from recess.
articles.abstract: People on Capitol Hill said the initial campaign for strikes against Syria proved unpersuasive, but administration officials insist the debate will continue when Congress returns from recess.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Each morning for the last week, at 7:45, more than a dozen White House aides have mustered in the corner office of President Obama’s chief of staff, Denis R. McDonough, to get their marching orders for what has become the most intense, uphill lobbying campaign of the Obama presidency.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: Facing Fury Over Antigay Law, Stoli Says ‘Russian? Not Really’
articles.snippet: A boycott of vodka by gay activists critical of Russia has focused on Stolichnaya, made in a nation with experience of Russian oppression.
articles.abstract: A boycott of vodka by gay activists critical of Russia has focused on Stolichnaya, made in a nation with experience of Russian oppression.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIGA, Latvia — When a number of prominent Americans, outraged by what they saw as a rising tide of state-sponsored homophobia in Russia, called for a boycott of Stolichnaya vodka this summer, they had no more eager ally against Moscow than Kaspars Zalitis, a gay rights advocate here in Latvia, a Baltic nation with a long and painful experience with Russia’s oppression of minorities.

articles.headline: With the World Watching, Syria Amassed Nerve Gas
articles.snippet: Despite an international effort to block it, Syria’s governing Assad family exploited large loopholes, lax enforcement and a far greater emphasis on limiting the spread of nuclear arms.
articles.abstract: Despite an international effort to block it, Syria’s governing Assad family exploited large loopholes, lax enforcement and a far greater emphasis on limiting the spread of nuclear arms.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Syria’s top leaders amassed one of the world’s largest stockpiles of chemical weapons with help from the Soviet Union and Iran, as well as Western European suppliers and even a handful of American companies, according to American diplomatic cables and declassified intelligence records.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Andrew W. Lehren and Rick Gladstone

articles.headline: Verizon-F.C.C. Court Fight Takes On Regulating Net
articles.snippet: Verizon and other companies that spent billions of dollars to build their Internet pipelines are fighting the F.C.C.
articles.abstract: Verizon and other companies that spent billions of dollars to build their Internet pipelines are fighting the F.C.C.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Few people would dispute that one of the biggest contributors to the extraordinary success of the Internet has been the ability of just about anyone to use it to offer any product, service or type of information they want.

articles.headline: Worries That Microsoft Is Growing Too Tricky to Manage
articles.snippet: Many feel that a more focused, nimble collection of mini-Microsofts could respond more effectively to the never-ending flow of disruptive technologies nibbling at its foundations.
articles.abstract: Many feel that a more focused, nimble collection of mini-Microsofts could respond more effectively to the never-ending flow of disruptive technologies nibbling at its foundations.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — At a time when many people in business believe the number of products at Microsoft should be getting smaller, it is about to become a lot bigger.

articles.headline: Apple Is Set to Announce Two iPhones
articles.snippet: One iPhone will feature a faster processor,  and the other will be a less expensive model in a variety of colors aimed at markets like China and India.
articles.abstract: One iPhone will feature a faster processor,  and the other will be a less expensive model in a variety of colors aimed at markets like China and India.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The handset market is so brutally competitive that Apple, the most successful smartphone maker, is preparing to step up its game this week by offering two new iPhones instead of one.

articles.headline: Harder Edge From Vanity Fair Chafes Some Big Hollywood Stars
articles.snippet: The magazine has sharpened its celebrity coverage and that has angered some in Hollywood.
articles.abstract: The magazine has sharpened its celebrity coverage and that has angered some in Hollywood.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, the relationship between Vanity Fair and Hollywood was like Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers: the magazine gave the movie business class and Hollywood gave Vanity Fair sex.

articles.headline: Picking Death Over Eviction
articles.snippet: Some farmers commit suicide to protest eviction, a reminder of how China’s new urbanization push is at times a violent struggle with a powerful state.
articles.abstract: Some farmers commit suicide to protest eviction, a reminder of how China’s new urbanization push is at times a violent struggle with a powerful state.
articles.lead_paragraph: As she drove down a busy four-lane road near her old home, Tang Huiqing pointed to the property where her dead sister’s workshop once stood. The lot was desolate, but for Ms. Tang it lives.

articles.headline: Inside the End of the U.S. Bid to Punish Lehman Executives
articles.snippet: Securities and Exchange Commission officials sparred for months before concluding that suing executives at Lehman Brothers over the bank’s 2008 collapse would be legally unjustified.
articles.abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission officials sparred for months before concluding that suing executives at Lehman Brothers over the bank’s 2008 collapse would be legally unjustified.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a closed-door meeting in early 2011, Wall Street regulators were close to throwing in the towel on their biggest case.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Susanne Craig

articles.headline: Latest Overhaul of the MGM Studio Appears to Be a Moneymaker
articles.snippet: After emerging from bankruptcy and cutting costs, the venerable studio is generating cash and has a number of movies and TV shows in the works.
articles.abstract: After emerging from bankruptcy and cutting costs, the venerable studio is generating cash and has a number of movies and TV shows in the works.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For much of the last decade, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has been troubled by financial turmoil and infuriating production stops and starts, including a debacle in which Tom Cruise helped run its United Artists label.

articles.headline: A Journalist-Agitator Facing Prison Over a Link
articles.snippet: No one has accused Barrett Brown, a journalist with ties to the hacker group Anonymous, of playing a role in the theft of data, only of posting a link to a trove of stolen documents.
articles.abstract: No one has accused Barrett Brown, a journalist with ties to the hacker group Anonymous, of playing a role in the theft of data, only of posting a link to a trove of stolen documents.
articles.lead_paragraph: Barrett Brown makes for a pretty complicated victim. A Dallas-based journalist obsessed with the government’s ties to private security firms, Mr. Brown has been in jail for a year, facing charges that carry a combined penalty of more than 100 years in prison.

articles.headline: A Quest to Save AM Before It’s Lost in the Static
articles.snippet: Already ailing, AM radio now is plagued by a new threat: rising interference from smartphones and consumer electronics that reduce many stations to little more than static.
articles.abstract: Already ailing, AM radio now is plagued by a new threat: rising interference from smartphones and consumer electronics that reduce many stations to little more than static.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Is anyone out there still listening?

articles.headline: On Both Sides, Syrians Make Pleas to U.S.
articles.snippet: As lawmakers prepare to debate a strike on the Assad government, Syrians on both sides of the issue work to influence Congress and the American public.
articles.abstract: As lawmakers prepare to debate a strike on the Assad government, Syrians on both sides of the issue work to influence Congress and the American public.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The video from Kafranbel, a rebel-held village in northern Syria, has been sent by e-mail to members of the United States Congress and posted repeatedly on their Web sites — often in long strings of comments about Syria that have flooded unrelated posts about health care or the openings of new constituent offices.

articles.headline: Obama Tests Limits of Power in Syrian Conflict
articles.snippet: President Obama’s approach to Syria is likely to create an important precedent in the often murky legal question of when presidents or nations may lawfully use military force.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s approach to Syria is likely to create an important precedent in the often murky legal question of when presidents or nations may lawfully use military force.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In asking Congress to authorize an attack on Syria over claims it used chemical weapons, President Obama has chosen to involve lawmakers in deciding whether to undertake a military intervention that in some respects resembles the limited types that many presidents — Ronald Reagan in Grenada, Bill Clinton in Kosovo and even Mr. Obama in Libya — have launched on their own.

articles.headline: Koch Brothers Make Offer of $7 Billion for Molex
articles.snippet: The deal, for a company that makes electronics plugs for a range of products including the iPhone 5, is the biggest by Koch Industries in eight years.
articles.abstract: The deal, for a company that makes electronics plugs for a range of products including the iPhone 5, is the biggest by Koch Industries in eight years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:55 p.m. | Charles and David Koch preside over a vast private empire that manufactures a dizzying array of products, from oil pipelines to Brawny paper towels.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced
